awd_titl_txt: EAGER: SSDIM: Ensembles of Interdependent Critical Infrastructure Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The need to represent and analyze socially coupled interdependent infrastructure networks poses significant scientific and technical challenges. A central challenge is the lack of realistic data sets that represent the networks, their interactions, and the points of connection with consumers. This EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will develop ensembles of such coupled systems, along with methods to assess concerns of data quality and validity. Ensembles of coupled power and communication networks will provide realistic data for algorithm development. The tools and techniques developed under the project will also be disseminated to the broader community of analysts and researchers interested in the science and engineering of complex networks. The work will result in unique open-access realistic data sets for the  academic and other interested communities. 

This project will develop mathematical techniques and associated algorithms for generating ensembles of infrastructure networks and social interactions. It will also yield methods for the validation and verification of these interdependent synthetic populations and network ensembles. A key focus will be on large, realistic power and communication networks. This work will lead to highly scalable, data-driven, dynamic methods for sensitivity analysis, uncertainty quantification, and verification and validation. The research will provide data to support new ways of characterizing and assessing vulnerabilities inherent in today's societal infrastructures. The ensemble of realistic networks will facilitate the study of vulnerabilities resulting from interdependencies among infrastructures as well as from vulnerabilities and risks that result from interaction of individuals with the infrastructure as well with each other.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The need to represent and analyze interdependent infrastructure networks poses significant scientific and technical challenges. One central challenge is the lack of realistic datasets that accurately represent the networks, their interactions, and the points of connection with consumers. In our NSF-funded project Ensembles of Interdependent Critical Infrastructure Networks, we focused on developing synthetic electrical power networks and creating quantitative models to evaluate U.S. residential energy demands with explicit regard for time and geographic location.

In order to coalesce the enormous amounts of diverse data involved in capturing daily energy usage, we created four separate pipelines to encapsulate details of important tasks in modern-day complex systems: data processing, modeling and simulation, validation, and parallelization. It is challenging to validate energy use data in households because numerous environmental and dwelling factors affect energy use. Ideally, we say that a synthetic dataset is representative of the real world if it satisfies the qualities of fidelity and diversity. Fidelity measures the degree to which synthetic data points are close to real data points. It measures the quality and representativeness of the synthetic data points. Diversity measures whether synthetic data covers the full variability in real data and captures how well certain behaviors and patterns in real data are captured by synthetic data. We performed preliminary evaluation on magnitude and load shape of energy use at different spatial and temporal resolutions, and validated patterns of energy use profiles of households using precision, recall, and coverage as the metrics.

In total we developed five energy models to simulate all the end-uses. The modeling framework was validated using both visual and quantitative metrics, and displayed interesting differences between regions and within regions, thus implying that energy consumption is highly variable and dependent on a large number of factors such as climate, time of data collection, representativeness of sample, number of samples in the collected data, and so on. Additionally, we observed high variation in energy-use between day-to-day and season-to-season for different climate zones as well as between different households and within a household. This illustrates some of the challenges in this work and the importance of capturing such variations well in order to support policy formation and decision making.

Data on electrical distribution networks are virtually non-existent, and we developed a framework to create ensembles of synthetic distribution electrical power networks that resemble the actual networks for any geographical region. Distribution networks consist of medium voltage (MV) primary- and low voltage (LV) secondary networks, and connect individual residences to substations. We obtained real world power distribution networks for the town of Blacksburg in southwest Virginia with the goal of comparing the structure of the generated synthetic distribution networks of the actual network of this region. Validation was performed (1) through verification that the generated networks satisfy power engineering operating principles, (2) through quantitative comparisons of network properties, and (3) through visual comparisons of networks, the latter enabled by the fact that they are spatially embedded.

Examples of use include numerical assessment of stability under normal operating conditions, operations under stress when the power grid is operating at or near capacity (e.g., due to heatwaves), and supporting planning when evaluating the impact of adding renewable energy sources to the grid and increased electrical vehicle adoption. We have also considered the problem of scheduling residential EV charging for multiple consumers while maintaining network reliability by ensuring that nodes in the network do not have undervoltage issues. This includes the additional challenge of restricted exchange of information: where the consumers do not have access to network information and the network operator does not have access to consumer load parameters. We have proposed a distributed framework which generates an optimal EV charging schedule for individual residential consumers based on their preferences and iteratively updates it until the network reliability constraints set by the operator are satisfied. Our validated results demonstrate that the new approach can achieve a higher level of network reliability compared to the case where residential consumers charge EVs based solely on their individual preferences, thus providing a solution for the existing grid to keep up with increased adoption rates without significant investments in increasing grid capacity.

These synthetic electrical distribution networks, in conjunction with the modeling we developed to simulate household energy required for things like refrigerators, lighting, and hot water, will allow for a range of stability analyses for the U.S. power grid. A model like this makes it possible to answer key questions related to electrical power consumption at the household level, and for systematic studies of the impact of economic incentives to end-consumers on energy usage. The stability of the power grid is of utmost importance to national security, and we feel that these models and synthetic datasets are interesting and useful contributions to a national-level solution.


 


Last Modified: 12/15/2022
Modified by: Madhav V Marathe
